column3: We paid $ 740.00 US dollars for an exclusive , Chichen Itza all inclusive Private Tour booked through the concierge ( Lucia ) at our Finest Resort on Playa Mujeres .

We were a party of four adults ( my husband , myself and our two adult daughters , one of whom had a birthday on our planned excursion date ) who have traveled extensively and made it specifically known to the concierge that we had previously been to this World Unesco Site and had read and studied the Mayan culture , we needed a guide who had an equal or superior knowledge to our own .
Things started out badly when 24 hours after booking the tour we received a call from Lucia telling us it would be $ 30 more than the advertised amount in the catalogue .
Our driver , Homero picked us up at the hotel at the agreed time .
As we drove our way out of the city it was clear Homero was in no mood to talk , or even provide information about our trip .
My husband and I made every attempt to engage this man in conversation , but he gave only short sentence responses and at times , and always speaking in a low voice , one word answers .
I should mention that we are completely bi-lingual and booked the tour in Spanish , so there was no problem concerning translation .

About 15 minutes into the drive Homero tells us he needs to stop for ice , and proceeds to enter the gas station store to get himself a coffee and buy ice for the cooler which contained water and drinks for our excursion .
Please note that this is not on the scheduled tour and took time away from our trip .
At this point I asked him who our tour guide would be once we arrived to Chichen Itza .
Imagine our shock and horror when he told us it was him !
I must mention here that Homero is a good driver , but is definitely NOT a worthy tour guide .
He only spoke when asked , and the tour consisted of a few laminated pictures as he explained his take on the Mayan culture .
Homero's personal views were at times , bordering on xenophobic , and his knowledge was rudimentary at best .
Homero seemed to know just about everyone at the site , and when leaving several other drivers were laughing at us and telling him to smile .
I ddi not spend over $ 700 to be mocked and belittled by a representative of a supposedly exclusive tour agency .
Our tour also consisted of lunch at a local restaurant , a visit to swim in a Cenote , and finally time in Valladolid .
When we arrived to Valladolid Homero pointed out the main square and the church from the van , and then said we would be leaving !
We were interested not only in taking some pictures , but also perhaps stopping to purchase some handcrafts at a local market .
He told us he had no place to park and would wait 15 minutes and then come back to pick us up .
We were unable to purchase souvnenirs due to HIS pressing need to leave ( so much for exclusive tour and our day ended on an additionally sour note .
I mentioned our huge disappointment to the concierge at the Finest Resort , and they thanked us for letting them know and that they would get in touch with Seasons Tours .
Seasons Tours never called us to give us an apology or explanation .
Finest Resorts would do well to no longer associate themselves with Seasons Tours unless they somehow make amends .
Our experience should be noted by others who are planning their private tours , let the buyer beware !
Take a site of interest , with ruins and stories to tell .
Add 1000 vendors of crappy t-shirt whose only objective is to distract you from your visit , making noise , and ruining the entire experience and visuals .
This place could be so much more if it was properly managed !
I seriously considered I have lost the day as I have been very , very disappointed .
Oh , did I mention that most tours pass by some crap yet expensive flea market before the visit ?
This is my second time visiting Chichen Itza , my first time was 8 years ago .

I must say I was very disappointed this time It is a wonderful legacy to to Mayan people but since the government took over it has gotten rather run down and even the interpretive signage are faded and unreadable .
It does not seem like they are taking very good care of this place anymore and it saddens me A beautiful place but not managed or maintained very well .
And adult admission was pretty pricey so do not tell me they can not afford to enshrine this magnificent wonder with all the respect and honour it deserves !
After having read so much about this place , I was under-whelmed by much that I saw .
Once able to escape the clutches of the throng of vendors , and paying too much to enter , it was a bit of a let-down .
Not as elaborate or exhilarating as expected and certainly not worth the price .
the only thing you will find is lots of people trying to scam you .
there is a front entrance that you turn right to get to .
if you go straight it will take you to the back entrance and the hotel that is back there .
walk through the hotel buy your ticket at the gate there .
saw it would not go near it5 i knew all these scams going there i had done my research .
not worth the time or expense , overrun with venders , you might as well go to a local flea market , many other great mayan sites where no venders are allowed inside .
It completely pulls you out of the experience and makes it feel like a spectacle and amusement park .

The most annoying part , besides the crowds of people ( tourist clapping to create echos everywhere ) and vendors , was the jaguar noises , the vendors have discovered noise makers that they can reproduce a pretty convincing , albeit obnoxious , jaguar sound .

They have decided that somehow this must entices tourists into buying , Maybe if ONE vendor had it , it would be fascinating and unique , but when every 2nd vendor is making a growling jaguar noise it gets pretty freaking annoying fast .
The first time I heard it , I thought it was a kid making the noise , then I heard it all day long everywhere I went , it was maddening .
do not never bother with the cenote either , it is nothing special at all and it is a long walkway of vendor valley .
Chichen Itza ( the ruins and structures ) are cool , amazing , even spectacular , but everything the comes along with it trumps that .
Advice to get a 5 / 5 excellent experience , rent a car , and then there first thing in the morning as soon as they open up .
Any tree on the site was cut down and only the perimeter where the hucsters harass us incessantly could you find a bit of shade .
After 2 / 12 hours on a hot overcrowded VIP bus we arrived .
I am pretty sure we were about 1 / 2 mile from the sun .
I was looking forward to going back after 12 years and I was very disappointed .
They have completely destroyed this once beautiful place with vendors selling crap from when you arrive to every square inch of shade inside the ruins .
My suggestion if you come here look at online pics and tell everyone you went and do not GO .
I was at Chichen itaz about 30 years ago and as far as the ruins are concerned , it is just as beautiful and amazing as they were 30 years ago .

What was beyond disappointing were the hundreds and hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of tables of litteral tourist junk that lines ever single inch of every single pathway throughout the entire site .

If that was not bad enough , someone has invented a jaguar call tool which is blown over and over and over again in your ears as your trying to take in the structures , with someone saying , just a dollar , just a dollar , a hundred times .
What in the world has happened that Mexico opted for some table rental space and sacraficed the beauty and awe of this historical wonder .
It just litterally distroys the experience I was once again expecting after 30 years .
The main pyramid has been fully reatored , thus it lacks any history and culture .
Arroved at opening , 8am , wandered to main site , all stalls are setting up .
By 1030 it was packed with thousands of tour groups , all clapping at the main pyramid .
For what we paid and size of the place its pony .
A tiny complex that is considered on a par with Machu Picchu and Petra , NOWAY !
Save you dollars , most tour pay upwards from $ 150 .
From the moment you arrive , until you leave , you are bombarded and pestered by hawkers and peddlers selling trashy imported souvenirs throughout the site .
The cultural significance of this wonderful Mayan site has been totally spoiled .
The hawkers display their wares on every pathway and throw their trash into once-pristine vegetation behind them , bottles , cans , plastics bags , broken chairs , etc .
We will NEVER return to what was once a favorite place to visit .
Chichen Itza is a must if you have any interest in Mexicos indigenous history .
First , they picked us up more than an hour late - It was supposed to be 7:50 .
Next , we went to a shop to buy overpriced trinkets .
To be fair , the explanation of what we were looking at was pretty good .
Not too difficult to see how the tour operator makes money .
Finally , we stopped at a lovely village for about 20 minutes .
In summary - Started at 7:50 AM , returned at 9:30 PM .
Two hours out of more than 13 hours at Chichen Itza .
Booked a Tui excursion to Chichen Itza , 5.20 am pick up , 3 hour drive , lucky we had a guide as we would not have known the history .
But I do not know how this is one of the new 7 wonders of the world ?

We then got taken to a cenotes where you could swim in the water after a lunch ( not the best as food Luke warm but chicken was hot ) and later a Mayan village Too long a day as I would have been ready to return after Chichen Itza and did not get back to resort after another 3 hour drive at about 6pm Beware lots of stalls trying to sell you stuff as you Walt to and back from the ruins .
We did not have to queue for the tickets for more than 2-3 minutes even though we got there around 12.00 .
We might have been lucky to go there in a day that was not that busy , because the site was not very crowded , so there were plenty of opportunities to take photos .
I would have expected to be given a map of the site with some info but they do not provided much info even though the entrance fee is quite steep .
There are way too many stalls selling the same souvenirs inside the site , all trying to engage in conversation with you , however there are very few benches or toilets .
Visitors would benefit much more from benches and toilets than having literally 100s of stalls selling the same thing .
If you are not taking a tour then the info you can read is very minimal , so better do a bit of research on Wikipedia to understand more about the buildings and areas .
The pathways are quite poor so prepare to walk on uneven surfaces , rocks and dirt .
There are many beautiful and striking buildings and areas , but the overall experience is ruined by the poor amenities .
Very nice place but way to many people and trash laying around this beautiful wonder .
It is the smallest of the seven wonders ( And maybe not really a wonder ) .
Go early in the morning so you get it for yourself .
We visited this site through a Viator Exclusive Early Access with Amigo Tours .

After several emails to their many email addresses they simply do not respond to confirm the pickup time until shortly before the trip , causing much anxiety , stress , and unnecessary phone calls which could be entirely avoided .
The visit to the site was very good , and the history was very interesting and enthusiastically told by our guide Rodrigo .

I personally felt that much of the history could have been explained on the journey , rather than wasting valuable time at the site listening to it as the temperature rose and the number if visitors increased .
Unfortunately , once we left the site it was all downhill from there .

We were taken to a souvenir shop before lunch , where the many shop assistants engaged us in small talk and stalked us around the shop trying to get us to buy things we were not interested in and were noticeably overpriced ( even compared to prices in our own hotel gift shop ) !
We felt the need to just wait outside after a while .
We were then shown into the restaurant where we were offered drinks and a mediocre lunch .
When it came time to leave , it came to everyone's shock and bemusement that we were asked to pay for our drinks , and it was drastically overpriced .
At no point were we offered a any warning about this , no menu , nor the opportunity to see any prices .
The final kick in the teeth came when the waiter had the audacity to say we owed him a tip as well .
We got up and left immediately and I was seething for a good while after .
The lesson here - by all means visit these fantastic ruins - just do not do it through Amigo Tours , they turned what should have been a fantastic day into an adequate one .
First thing to note is that these excursions are not cheap .
However , you are away from your hotel for 12 hours and taken to Chichen Itza , a traditional Mayan village ( with Cenote ) and a pretty little town ( sorry , can not remember what it was called ) .
1 ) Chichen Itza - my issue with this was our tour guide rather than the site itself .
He was half Mexican / Austrian , his English was good , but I think a bit was lost in translation .
The only way I can describe it was that , to me , he was telling us stuff in blocks , just not sure the blocks were in the right order .
I am not a member of Mensa , but I also do not think I am the dimmest lightbulb in the box , but this guy just lost me completely !
He rattled off that many numbers , I seriously thought that instead of the umbrella I had brought to shelter me from the sun , I should have brought a ready reckoner or a calculator !
The salt mines just outside of Krakow should feel really aggrieved that they never made it into the top seven and this did .
2 ) Mayan Village - this was a really good part of the trip .
Cenote , traditional Mayan village , Tequila factory and our lunch stop .
3 ) Town - really pretty town centre , but not there long enough to comment on it .
Bus - quite a bit of alcohol provided , which was good and our guide was quite amusing in bits .
Summary - if in this part of the world , then you have to visit Chichen Itza - it is a New Seven Wonder of the World after all .
However , if you are not an early riser , then do not consider it , we had to be ready and standing at reception for 5:25am !
Having been to Tikal just 3 days prior , this was a tad of disappointment .
There were stalls everywhere selling crafts , we felt we were at a market place more than a ruin historical site .
Obviously I am not actually reviewing the temples themselves here ( because those are just amazing ) but just the site itself .
Main tip is go early - as soon as it opens at 8am .
At 10am is when all the massive tour buses start to arrive ( the scourge of all tourist sites ) so you get biiiig queues and huge groups of people with selfie sticks but without self awareness .
If you go at 8am you are virtually on your own apart from a few dozen people .
Take a guide book because there is not much information provided at the actual site so you will not know what anything is .
Also be prepared for a lot of vendors selling blankets , masks , ornaments , magnets , hats etc .
it is almost more like going to a market that happens to have a temple on-site .
I actually quite like the vendors because they were not too pushy or anything and one or two ( out of the hundreds ) did actually have some nice stuff .
Also take water and snacks with you because the restaurant / shop there is very limited and very expensive .

If you are driving there ( as we did ) be aware the car park does not actually seem to open to visitors ( as Lonely Planet says it is - it is only for tour buses , taxis , staff etc ) so you have to park about 1km away ( in a sort of field , just off the main road that leads to Chichen Itza ) .
Alternatively you could park in the town nearby and get a taxi that will drop you off right in front of the entrance .
I have written three reviews of recent Mayan ruin visits - Tulum , Coba and now Chichen Itza .
By all accounts , this last one was to be the best one , as Chichen Itza is the most visited of all the ruins .
It is classified as one of the 7 modern wonders of the world .
So , let me give you the view that we had when we visited .
First , it is a 2 + hour drive from the Tulum area .
When you arrive , you are confronted by too many cars , too few parking spots , and many , many tour buses .
The entrance is over-commercialized to the point of being a put-off .
And , the concessions run right up to , and along all of the major walkways around the site .
To be fair , one could say that this is the way it looked at its height of power and dense occupation , but I think not .
The main temple , Castillo Temple , is indeed impressive , as is the grand ballgame court and the Temple of the Warriors .
There is a mystic attached to the large cenote , Cenote Sagrada , but it is truthfully an unappealing , dirty and trashy cenote .
It appears that the main attraction today for Chichen Itza is selfies in front of the Castillo Temple .
If the sight were reserved and preserved , and without all of the commercialization , it could be a true wonder .
One could actually step back in time , marvel at the ingenuity and scale , and imagine what it was like at its zenith .
The city was the most powerful in the region , and lasted from around 500-1,600 AD , when the spanish came .
Archeologists have found that the current main temple is actually built over the earlier temple .
Excavations have uncovered original stone carvings and paintings , including some semi-precious embedded stones .
If you go to the Yucatan and you intend on seeing ruins , then you should include Chichen Itza .
Just go when they first open , to avoid the masses of cars , busses , people , baby carriages , vendors and barkers , and the cacophony of otherwise uninterested and irreverent selfers .
There are better options at to experience the Mayan culture at Tulum and Coba .
We went on a tour bus , which had a narrator on the whole 2.5 hours journey .
Part way through it we had to stop at a village which amazingly enough was a big souviener shop , with products supposedly made by the local Mayans .
It was uncomfortable at best , if you did not buy anything .
When we arrived at Chichen Itza , the bus guide turned us over to another guide who had been on the bus the whole time .
The number of vendors was so overwhelming one did not get an opportunity to actually absorb the incredible feats that the Mayans accomplished over 2000 years ago .
Through paths lined with vendors one was constantly approached or interrupted and we felt we just wanted to run into the open space near the large temple .
The second guide had us stand in sweltering heat in various places for about a total of an hour and basically repeated the same story we had just heard .
We never did learn how it was built , why it was built except that on occasion there were human sacrifices and that it told them when the equinoxes happened .
The ball stadium was interesting and finally almost free of vendors .
We had about half hour free time but most of that was spent on avoiding vendors stalls .
The temple is fenced off and no entry allowed due to vandalism and accidents prior to 2007 .
This could have been a great cultural experience but not so .

At the end of our half hour free time we met back at a pre-arranged restaurant , which I must say served good food and the entertainment was unique in that they had local dancers in full costume there at the end of dinner .
We visited Chichen Itza after visiting Uxmal and the sun and moon pyramids in Mexico city , and Chichen Itza has been the least interesting and the most crowded of all three .
do not get me wrong , it is still worth a visit , but probably an hour and half would do , and if you have to pick one place to visit , then you have better choices .
No disrespect to the New 7 Wonders of the World rating , but we thought this was just ok .
Did not think it was worth fighting for parking amidst endless buses , then fighting the crowds .
And the number of vendors flogging the same stuff was ridiculous .
The ruins of Chitchen Itz are zone of the Steven wonders of the world but the guide dedicated us only one hour of time , illustrating the Temple of Kukulkan and the Ball Court .
We already thank wikipedia for the informations about , i.eprd the Temple of the Warriors , La Iglesias , El Caracol , the Sacred Cenote .
This is an incredible place , easy to see why it has its 7th wonder of the modern world status .
However , the site is overrun with stalls selling tourists souvenirs , you are constantly called out to , which when you are on a tour & trying to listen to your guide is really irritating .

Our tour was booked through Thomas Cook , who use Iberotours , the coach arrived late , the tour stopped half way round the site ( I think due to time pressures ) & the lunch at the hotel on the side of the site was mediocre at best .

Our tour guide made a big deal of the traditional dancers who perform during the meal , it was pretty underwhelming - performers looked exceptionally bored , the dance consisted of stamping on a crate with a beer bottle on your head , odd .
We were also due to stop in a traditional Mayan town en route back to the hotel , again time was an issue again with just 25 minutes to look around .
Obviously this review goes beyond Chichen Itza , but it does give a reflection of how most tour days are structured .
do not get me wrong , the ruins are majestic , although nothing beats the Giza pyramids in Kairo .
But if you have limited time for your holiday , getting from the coast to the ruins and back is a full-day trip .
In addition , the queuing took almost an hour , and in the ruins we actually spent more time watching the artwork and souvenir shops of the Mayan people than the actual ruins .
Well , maybe we should have asked for a tour guide to get more out of it .
In comparison , the next day we went to Tulum to see the ruins , and that place was actually much nicer for visitor , it was more like walking in a garden next to the sea .
So if i had to choose between these two , I would pick Tulum .
I was really looking forward to this visit but when I got there , all I could see were vendors and more vendors , all selling the same touristy souvenirs and all bugging you to buy something .
Inside , the main pyramid was also closed off , so you can not go inside or climb the chairs .
Our tour guide did give us a lot of information and history which was helpful in interesting .
But I could not help to feel a bit disappointed when I left .
As an avid visitor to ancient civilization ruins around the world , I found Chichen Itza to be a disappointment .

While the history lf the Mayans is a very interesting story , and gaining new knowledge and insight into their expertise in astronomy and mathematics was enjoyable , the ruins themselves were a bit of a let down .

In recent history , they were privately owned by a family who did not appear to have regard for their historical worth and although it has been many years since the property was sold to the Mexican government , this disregard is still quite evident .
As excursions go , this was nothing more than a money grab by the Mexican people playing on the tourists emotions .

Having your Mayan birth certificate created sounds very interesting and unique , and at a reasonable cost for such uniqueness , it ends up being a joke , but you do not know that , having paid for something in the morning and not seeing the product until the end of the tour .

At the site itself you hounded constantly by the poverty stricken Mayans , only to be taken to a nearby colonial town later in the day where you see these same people living a happy and very comfortable cosmopolitan lifestyle .

You are presented with a souvenir bottle of a Mayan recipe liquor while on the return bus tip by a young man who is sole income is shyly but very persuasively earned by selling you a very expensive , horrible tasting concoction that is bottled with a custom label glued on featuring YOU standing in front of the temple at Chitchen Itza , a photo that you never actual posed for .

Before arriving at the ruins you are taken to the only shop vendor who can be trusted where someone photographs you getting off the bus the Photoshops the image of the ruin , puts it on a bottle and later in the day this bottle is presented to you in a manner which makes it very difficult to refuse paying for .
The Mexicans are renowned ofcourse , for being expert manipulators of the tourists wallets .

The cost of the excursion was $ 109 USD and was 12 hours long , but only two hours were actually spent at the ruins , on a guided tour , leaving you no time for photos or exploration , although one would be free to do so given the time .

It does not matter which excursion company you book with because , except for the price , the they all follow exactly the same routine , timed expertly so that only one or two bus loads arrive at any given time , but each tour experiencing exactly the same thing .
Chichen Itza is awe inspiring , but I am not sure putting up with the rest of the hassle that goes along with the excursion makes it worth seeing .
The ruins and grounds are beautiful but like most things it eventually turns into a huge tourist trap so I was a little disappointed .
Has every thing you would want on a day out , toilets cafes and shops for gifts .
Such a fantastic historic sight , what a shame there is no hands on .
I had expected to be able to climb the famous pyramid , but all the temples are roped off to the public .
Also constantly hassled by traders who have access to the site .
I recommend a dip in the cenote ( Xal-Ha ) on the way home as this is only a few minutes drive away .
We were there in the July and it was hot and humid .

Too bad someone drew something on wall of the pyramid before we went there , so the stairway to the top of the pyramid was blocked off , we could not go to up to the top to have a better view of the area .
There were quite a few vendors selling souvenir at the entrance , and also at the exit of site .
I have been to the pyramid in Egypt , you you have to go underground from the inside of the pyramid , but the Chichen itza you actually can go up from outside less secretive .
But too bad we did not get a chance to go in .
Apart from the temples in Chichen Itsa there is nothing else to see .
It is a great experience to say you have visited one of the wonders of the world but that is it .
We have not regretted the visit , but I would suggest if you have time also visit Tulum to full fill the whole experience .
My wife and I went to Chichen Itza when we were in Cancun .
The only reason I would suggest it is Chichen Itza is one of the Seven Modern Wonders of the World .
And of the Seven , it probably ranks 7th and I have been to them all .
Once you have been , there is no reason to ever go back .
Chichen Itza is a 2 hour bus ride from Cancun so basically it is a day tour from your hotel .
Our tour guide said that lunch was provided but all we got was a cheese sandwich and a juice box .
It is roped off now so you can not even walk up it all you can do is look .
You probably only need two hours to see the entire grounds .
We had a tour guide as part of our package so it was interesting to hear about the history of Chichen Itza .
One thing that I had seen in documentaries that I had not expected to see in Chichen Itza was the Great Ball Court .
This was supposed to be the first basketball type game ever played .
Be sure to shop around to try to get the best price as most booths sell same souvenirs .
If I could make one suggestion that would be go as early as possible .
Our tour arrived at 9:00 so we were able to take some great photos before the masses arrived .
I have uploaded pictures of the park for you to get a better picture of what it is like .
If you found my review helpful , please let me know that by clicking the Helpful Button .
It was a great experience to see and be there , however there are closer locations that will provide the same result .
I visited Chichen Itza in my way from Merida to Cancun .
The place is just fantastic , it makes you wonder how it was like when it was a thriving place of religion , rest , market and day-to-day life .
The place is not only a UNESCO world heritage site but also considered a wonder of the World , Right ?
Thousands of vendors and lots of tents inside the space where the monuments are .
The tents even cover most of the view of the place .
If this is a historic place that needs to be preserved , all those vendors and tents and rubbish they produce are not contributing to it .
Why the vendors are not kept outside the area , just at the entrance , I wonder ?
I am still a bit confused as to why this has been added to the list of World Wonders .
What could be the world wonder is hidden deep inside behind lock and key in the pyramid itself .
To get to the actual site you have to pass through a gauntlet of vendors .
Then when I reached the pyramid itself , it is much , smaller than I was expecting .
I do not what I was expecting but the entire area is surrounded by vendors who incessantly blow whistles mimicking jaguar growls and local bird-trills .
Al the surrounding buildings are half broken and behind roped off areas .
The cenote is not even reachable - would have been so nice to do a swim in the area to cool off and the sun is hot in the open field areas .
Mostly because you have to so you can say you did but sigh .
can not visit Mexico without visiting one of the 7 wonders , and the ruins themselves were incredible .
We were on an organised tour in the searing heat , the guide had an umbrella but unfortunately they were not given to us .
The information given was good but seemed superficial considering the size of the site , and we were only there a couple of hours .

I can only reinforce what others have said about the street vendors , it is like putting a flea market on the site of stone-henge , absolutely unbelievable , cheaper than Walmart , 1 dollar , almost free !
We had a good lunch at a tourist site with a bazaar where we were encouraged to buy from the locals , then I stop at a cenote which I have already reviewed as human soup !
Glad to have visited but disappointed by how the Mexican people allow their culture to be represented to tourists .
Chichen Itza is one of those places you should visit , but I would not consider it a 7th wonder of the world .
Go to Machu Picchu , Easter Island if you want to see some stellar man-made wonders .
We went last week ( May so the heat may have added to it .
The one thing that did not help was with all the sellers INSIDE the Mayan ruins .

It was horrible and you could NOT get away from any of the sellers , below are a few of their FAVORITE slogans ( even though they do not understand it Cheaper than Wal-Mart $ 1 only ( when in fact everything was $ 10 USD Cheaper on the way back .
One facade that the sellers try to promote to you is all the wooden items are hand-made , it is NOT .
You will notice that as you walk , some of the sellers will continually sand down on a wooden mask .
They will keep doing this to make you assume that they themselves hand made those items , Do NOT buy them !
There was only 1 person I saw chopping the wooden pieces down to size and he was in the back , heads down doing it .
I would rather recommend going to TULUM for those ruins there .
It is actually a lot more peaceful and just as beautiful .
Nice to see , but bus ride and stops took entire day .
We left hotel at 5am and got there before the crowds and the heat .
Our guide was fantastic and showed us so many unique things from clapping in front of the temple to whispering on the wind and being heard 200 metres away .
The history of the place is amazing and there is plenty of bird and animal life around .
This was my second visit to the site but the first with my daughter .
On the first tour I had gone as part of a large tour group and it was really disappointing as we did not get to wander or have a proper look around .
This time we went early and got a private guide which let us avoid both the crowds which build during the day and the heat of the afternoon .
there is a lot of walking and both times I have visited it is been really sunny and hot so use sunblock and have water with you .
There lots of shade though so you can stop , rest and cool down .
You can either download maps , by maps or guides or use a guide or tour .
I would downloaded a map but also had the private guide so when we had free time at the end we could still find our way around .
This is a large , historically and culturally important site and is very popular so like most locations like this it gets busy and crowded .
Going as early as possible means you get better photos with less people and the morning sun tends to be a little better for photography .
The private guide was great and gave us really good info and showed us really interesting things like special spots on buildings or sounds effects .
We could ask as little or as much as we liked and some bits we spent more time on than others .

It was a really relaxed and flexible way of doing it , by contrast the tour group I had done was very prescriptive and glossed over some bits , missed others entirely and spent ages giving a spiel that they had learnt .
there is only so many times you can hear about the glories of the Mayan calendar .
The buildings and sites are great , full of history and details and when it was not crowded had a nice older atmosphere , you could sense the history .
it is a lot of walking especially if you go to some of the more out of the way bits at the back behind the main popular area but well worth it .
My daughter , who is not as big a history nerd as I am , was surprised by how much she enjoyed it and had been expecting to be bored but loved Chichen Itza and was a highlight for her of our trip .
Go and see it in person , it is hard to really get a sense of how good it is from photos .
Loved it , have seen it twice and would go again .
We went with a fabulous company that provided breakfast , snacks and drinks on the coach .
The journey from Cancun is a bit long - over two hours .
The heat is unbelievably intense at Chichen Itza but luckily we were provided with umbrellas .

History & Culture - Chichen Itza is obviously known as one of the 7 Wonders of the world , and there are many interesting structures to study , admire , and be inspired .
However , the level of enjoyment would be greatly enhanced if one was to do some research about the Mayan culture and their calendar prior to the visit .
Otherwise , the experience would be limited or enhanced at the whim and the quality of the English speaking guides .
We had two guides , and both of them were very nice .
Unfortunately , they do feel much more comfortable in their native tongue so much of their comments were aimed at the Spanish speaking .
Vendors - They were everywhere but surprisingly not overly pushy as some other tourist traps I have visited .
They are also very open to bargaining - they must expect it as well .
How to get the best deal - ask them for their bottom first , then lower it by at least half .
If they do not accept , just walk away , they will give you a better offer .
If they do not accept your offer , then return later and use the last price as a base price to negotiate from .
do not worry , it is all very good-natured as they do appreciate the business and the interaction - haggling is probably part of their nature anyways .
The best price on the return visit will be close to the best deal .
If you have time , you can use this strategy for bargains and for mutual entertainment .
Length of the Tour - Chichen Itza is about 2.5 hours away by bus , and the bus makes multiple station stops to pick up other visitors , so the trip takes longer than the distance suggests .
Furthermore , the larger the touring party , the longer the wait between points of interest because everyone seems to pick up the Mexican culture of showing no respect for time whatsoever .
Just be aware and be patient , it is par for the course .
